title: Bernanke: More executives should have been prosecuted for financial crisis
text:
16.05 +1.04 
The former Fed chairman has said he would have liked to have seen more individuals punished for the roles they played in the crash 
More executives should have been sent to prison for the roles they played in the financial crisis, Ben Bernanke, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve, has said. 
Mr Bernanke, who stepped down from the American central bank last year, was in the eye of the storm when the global financial system was plunged into turmoil in 2008. 
He has told USA Today he would have preferred that the US Justice Department and other law enforcement agencies that probed the crash had concentrated further on individuals, not just on financial institutions. 
"It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) would have been my preference to have more investigation of individual action, since obviously everything what went wrong or was illegal was done by some individual, not by an abstract firm," he said. 
The former Fed chairman added that "the Fed is not a law enforcement agency". 
He said: "The Department of Justice and others are responsible for that, and a lot of their efforts have been to indict or threaten to indict financial firms. 
"Now (NYSE: DNOW - news ) a financial firm is of course a legal fiction; it's not a person. You can't put a financial firm in jail." 
Mr Bernanke, who speaking to the American newspaper ahead of the publication of his memoirs , said that "we were very, very determined not to let" Lehman Brother collapse, but that " we were out of bullets at that point ". The bankruptcy of Lehman in September 2008 sent global markets into a tailspin. 
His successor, Janet Yellen, now has to decide whether the US economy is strong enough to cope with the first interest rate rise since 2006. 
"You know, the last thing I want to do is second-guessing Janet Yellen, who I think is doing a really good job and making some tough calls," Mr Bernanke said. 
"But clearly there are some tough decisions to make on how to manage policy at this point, and this is a very important juncture."
